title: 111_hr3694
content: The Act may be cited as the "Removing Excess Litigation Involving Energy on Federal Lands Act" or the "RELIEF Act." The United States spends over $1 billion per day on importing crude oil, which is the largest wealth transfer in history. There are significant oil and gas reserves in the outer Continental Shelf, but legal challenges by environmental groups delay or prevent access to these resources, costing the American public and economy. Congress deems expedited judicial review necessary to address this abuse of the judicial system. Exclusive jurisdiction over causes and claims related to covered energy projects is granted to the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. All complaints must be filed within 60 days of the action or decision by a Federal official, or they will be barred. SEC. 5. District Court for the District of Columbia must resolve all proceedings subject to section 3 within 180 days, taking precedence over other matters. Failure to comply results in dismissal with prejudice. SEC. 6. Only the Supreme Court can review judgments from the district court. SEC. 7. Deadline for appeal to the Supreme Court. SEC. 6 states that only the Supreme Court can review judgments from the district court. SEC. 7 establishes a deadline for appeals to the Supreme Court, ensuring expedited resolution within 180 days. SEC. 8 sets limitations on the scope of review and relief. SEC. 8 limits judicial review of Federal actions under the Act, presuming administrative findings correct unless proven otherwise. Prospective relief can only be granted if narrowly drawn and least intrusive. SEC. 9 of the Act addresses legal fees for judicial review petitions, requiring non-prevailing parties to pay fees to prevailing parties unless special circumstances apply. SEC. 10 excludes disputes over lease obligations from the Act's scope, while SEC. 11 defines a covered energy project. SEC. 10 of the Act excludes disputes over lease obligations from its scope. SEC. 11 defines a covered energy project as actions or decisions by Federal officials regarding leasing Federal lands for energy exploration, development, or production.
